Chapter 6: Refuting Extreme Attachments, Refuting Extreme Attachments. Thus, the sense faculties and objects have all been shown to be false. In order to further wash away the defilements of extreme attachments to non-true sentence meanings, a verse is spoken:
If dharmas really exist, they should not be established in dependence on others;
Since they must be established in dependence on others, one should know they definitely do not really exist.
The treatise says:
If the nature and characteristics of all dharmas really exist, they should not be established in dependence on others.

Since form and other dharmas must be established in dependence on others, this and the other shore definitely do not really exist.ğŸ”½The sentence meaning of real and so forth grasped by the owl must be manifested by causes such as existence;
The sentence meaning of existence and so forth again depend on real and so forth as their own basis in order to be cognized.

Moreover, form and so forth are manifested in dependence on their own causes and conditions and on light and so forth. We do not see that the substance of form and so forth is independent. Therefore form and so forth do not really exist.

If you say that although the names of this shore and the other shore are established in dependence on each other, the substance of this shore and the other shore really exist, because they are form and so forth, the example is not established.
This statement is not correct.

The substance of form and so forth is not different in dependence on each other, but this shore and the other shore are different in dependence on each other. Therefore this shore and the other shore are not form and so forth. Their substance is not real, and the example is established.

Moreover, the meanings of the categories such as substance that are accepted by the other party are like empty flowers if they are established without a cause. If they are established with a cause, they are like illusions. Therefore you cannot accept that their substance really exists.

In the SÄá¹ƒkhya school, form and so forth are not separate from pleasure and so forth and are established in dependence on pleasure and so forth. Pleasure and so forth should also be established in dependence on something else.
If this is not so, there would be no transformation.
Whether there is a cause or not, the categories are the same as those discussed previously.
Therefore, form and so forth are not real in substance.

Moreover, the non-Buddhist schools hold that there are such things as pots, but they cannot be established as either identical with or different from form, because they must depend on something else for their cognition, like the previously mentioned analogies, which are not real in substance.
One cannot say that pots and so forth are identical with form, because pots are cognized in dependence on form, and so they do not depend on something else.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
There is no pot in form.
The treatise states:
A pot cannot be established as identical with the substance of form, because sound and so forth would also become the intrinsic nature of the pot.
Form is not the intrinsic nature of sound and so forth. How can it be established that form is precisely the pot?
Sound and so forth should also not be the very substance of the pot, because the meaning is the same as the refutation of form. Therefore, it is not discussed separately.
Moreover, each pot has many dharmas as its substance, but form and so forth are not like this. How can it be precisely the pot?
Color, etc., would be the same as the pot, and the pot would be the same as color, etc. Therefore, it cannot be said that the pot and color, etc., are both real and identical.
If it is said that when the substance of color is scattered, the substance is not the pot but becomes the pot,
then it should also be said that when the substance of color is scattered, the substance is color but becomes non-color.

If when color is aggregated it is both the pot and color, then one dharma would have two characteristics. This has already been refuted earlier. The substance would become many. Therefore, pots, etc., are not identical to color, etc.
There are some who say:
There are pots apart from color, because the qualities and substance are different. There should not be this fault.
The pot is only known in dependence on existence, etc. This is provisional, not real. It has already been explained above.
Moreover, one cannot grasp that there are pots apart from color.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
There are no pots apart from color.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Apart from form, etc., there is no real substance, and such things as pots and clothes are the supports of form, etc.
Why is this?
If such things as pots and clothes are not form, etc., they should be like space, etc., and not the supports of form, etc.
Then there should be no such things as pots and clothes, because they lack unique qualities, just like mind.
Mind must be nonexistent, because it is impermanent, as previously refuted. Self, space, etc., are also like this. Therefore, pots, etc., are not apart from form, etc.
If they are not apart from or identical to, the meaning is not established.
It should be established that such things as pots are all empty.
Moreover, the principle of such things as pots and form, etc., mutually supporting each other is not so. Therefore, the next verse says:
There is no form supported by a pot, nor is there a pot supported by form.
The treatise says:
The substance of such things as pots and form, etc., are all unreal. How can they be established as support and supported?
Here, the word support may express the meaning of cause. It is intended to show that real qualities are not established as cause and effect.
The son of KÄkÄsyaka holds that such effects as color, etc., have as their causes such things as pots, etc., which is contrary to inference.

That is, color, etc., do not have pots, etc., as their causes, because they are signified by such terms as â€œcolor,â€ etc., and because they are objects perceived by the mind that grasps color, etc., just as such qualities of the self as permanence have no causes.
The SÄá¹ƒkhyas hold that such effects as pots, etc., have as their causes such things as color, etc., which is also contrary to inference.
That is, pots, etc., do not have color, etc., as their causes, because they are not separate from them, because they are of the nature of pleasure, etc., just as color, etc., are.
They hold that color, etc., and existence are neither identical nor different. If they are not identical, existence must be like the horns of a rabbit and not the cause of pots, etc.
If you say that color, etc., are identical with existence, then they must be the same in substance and there can be no distinctions.

If you say that color, etc., are by nature pleasure, etc., and that there is no error in admitting that their substance is the same, this is also not so, because you contradict your own doctrine that the sense organs and their objects are different.
There is also a great error, because pleasure, suffering, and delusion would have the same nature, and there would be no difference.

If it is said that pleasure, etc. are not of the nature of existence, they should be completely non-existent like the horns of a rabbit. Form, etc. should also be the same as that, because they are inseparable.
Like the three of pleasure, etc., all are not really existent. Therefore, form, etc. are not the causes of vases, etc.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
Their establishment of the same nature as the dharmas has this error;
I establish the same nature as the dharmas as different.
Because the characteristics are different, there should be no such error.
The dharmas, when compared with each other, have the same and the different. The essence of the dharmas is limited and separate, so they are called different;
The nature of existence is comprehensive and pervasive, so it is called the same.ğŸ”½Since the comprehensive and limited are different, the characteristics have differences.
Because the characteristics are different, there is the same outside of the different.
If so, the meaning of the same and different should be established as having the same outside of different natures, because there is the same and there is difference, just like the same dharmas.
If it is said that this is not so, because the objects of this same and different nature are different, there is no same outside of different.
The objects of the same dharmas are the same, so there is the same outside of dharmas.
If so, the various dharmas should have a different nature.
Why is it so?
Therefore, the next verse says:
If one sees the two characteristics as different, namely, the same apart from the pot;
Since the two characteristics are already different, there should be difference apart from the pot.
The treatise says:
If one sees the characteristics of the same and different of various dharmas as different, then one establishes the same as existing outside of dharmas.
Since one sees the characteristics of the same and different of various dharmas as distinct, one should establish difference as existing outside of dharmas.
The two characteristics of the same and different are both universal to all dharmas. Difference should be like the same, existing separately from dharmas.
Even if one allows that there is difference and the same outside of dharmas, this should again have the nature of the same and different.
If this continues in an infinite regress, then the difference between the two characteristics cannot be known, because both are all-pervading and both are infinite.

If difference is the same as sameness, it should be called sameness, not difference. If sameness is the same as difference, it should be called difference, not sameness. Therefore, outside of dharmas there is no separate sameness or difference.
Moreover, if real, etc., are different from existence, they should not be able to know that reality, etc., exist.

The cognition that grasps specific characteristics cannot accurately cognize other dharmas with specific characteristics. This has already been fully explained. How can the world give rise to the cognition of existence regarding dharmas such as reality that are not existent?

If it is said that although reality, etc., are not existent, because they combine with existence, the cognition of existence arises, then dharmas such as reality are provisionally called existent, but their substance is not truly existent. It should be said that they are nonexistent, just as the people of the border regions establish eating, establish defecation, do not wash after defecation, and do not chew on willow branches, and are provisionally called cows, but are not true cows or calves.
Reality, etc., are also like this, provisionally existent but truly nonexistent.
Moreover, you should say:
What is the true remainder that is combined with existence and provisionally called existence?
If it is said that existence is truly existent, the reasoning is not so, because there is no difference.
Existence and reality, etc. are equally cognized by wisdom. How can it be said that one is true and one is provisional?
Moreover, if true existence and provisional existence are not one, the characteristics cognized by wisdom should be different, like a king and the king's emissary.
Moreover, it is said that the substance of reality, etc. is each different, while the nature of existence is the same, therefore it is different from existence.
This is also not so.
The true substance of reality, etc. is also without difference, but the functions can be distinguished as equal.
The nature of existence is also like this, with different functions. How can it be definitely grasped that existence is different from reality, etc.?
Why is this?

Because they are both knowable, because they are both not non-existent, and because they have the same function, they should mutually resemble each other, all being different and all being the same. Therefore, the nature of existence is not separate from reality, etc.
Next, we should now ask them:
If there is a nature external to dharmas, what analogy can be used to know it truly exists?
If it is said that like a single basis, the realities have distinct characteristics and do not produce numerical cognition,
one number is the same and can produce numerical cognition. Dharmas and numbers combined are called one pot and so forth.
Because of the difference in characteristics, realities are not one. Existence differs from dharmas. This is the common analogy.
If so, pots and so forth are not known by a single cognition, because their substance is not one, like two, three, and so forth.

If it is said that although the substance of pots and so forth is not one, they are called one because they are combined as one, then this one, although not being pots and so forth, should be called pots and so forth because it is combined with pots and so forth.
To illustrate this meaning, the next verse says:
If one is not called a pot, a pot should not be called one.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½For example, like one number combined with realities is not called realities;
in the same way, although realities are combined with one, they should not be called one.
because the meanings of the two are not different, and the world should not be called a single jar, etc.
Moreover, when reality, etc., combine with oneness, do they become one characteristic?
Or is it not so?
If they become one characteristic, they should abandon reality, etc., because the characteristic of oneness is not the substance of reality, etc.
If they abandon reality, etc., the number one should not exist, because number must be established based on reality, etc.
If it is said that reality, etc., do not become one characteristic, they should not be cognized by a single cognition or expressed by a single word.
Although they combine with it, their substance is not that, just as space, when combined with a person, is cognized and spoken of separately.
If it is like a spear, etc., which, because of combining with a person, although different from a person, is given the name of a person,
that reasoning is not so, because it is a provisional designation.
If it is said that reality, etc., are called one, that is also a provisional designation;
the reasoning is also not so, because there is no true oneness.
If it is said that the number one is true oneness, the reasoning is also not so, because cognition and words are the same.
If you say that the number one pervades real things and so on, but real things and so on do not pervade one, therefore one is not real.
This reasoning is also incorrect, because it has already been refuted.
That is to say, it should not be the object of a single cognition. Real things and so on should also not be truly different.

Since the words for the cognition of number that arises in regard to real things and so on are said to be provisional, the words for the cognition of real things and so on in regard to number should also be the same.
Because the words for the cognition of mutual dependence are not different in the two cases, how can you say that one is provisional and one is real?

Therefore, the argument is stated: The grasped real things and so on are not real things and so on, because they are the objects of the cognition of number and the words for number, just like one, two, and so on.
The grasped one is not the real substance of number, because it is the object of the words for the cognition of real things and so on, just like real things and so on.
Therefore, all of them are not real in substance.
Moreover, number and real things have never been combined. How can you say that a pot is combined with one and call the pot one?
Why is this so?
Therefore, the next verse says:
If a pot is never combined with one, the pot should not have the name one.
The treatise says:
If the real [pot] is in the empty space, and one [pot] is in the real [pot], since the locations are different, how can they be said to be combined?
Then one number should not indicate one pot, because the locations are different, just like the numbers two and so forth.
If it is said:
Because the supported and the support mutually pervade each other, they are called combined.
This is also not so, therefore the next verse says:
If form pervades the real, form should obtain the name great;
If the opponent's argument is not from another, one should state one's own doctrine.
The treatise says:
If the qualities such as form pervade the real that is the support, they should, like the real substance, also obtain the name great.
Since the locations such as earth are vast and obtain the name great, why are form and so forth not great?
Moreover, the qualities such as form should have shape and obstruction, because they are called earth and so forth, just like earth and so forth.
Then form and so on would not depend on others to be established, because they have shape and obstruction.
Like the real basis, they would have shape and obstruction, and their locations would not be the same. The real and the qualities would not be cause and effect.
There are many faults like this. The thesis you establish would be scattered and destroyed.
If you say that form and so on are included in the category of qualities, so they have no shape and obstruction,
this is also not so.
The opponent is not another. You should state your own thesis. Facing the opponent, you yourself describe it as useless.

In our Buddhist teaching, those who are wise, brave, and see the truth, regarding the six categories you uphold, regard them as incoherent babbling, without any respectful mind. What benefit is there in just drawing this?
Or, when form and so on depend on earth and so on, do they transform as a part?
Are they transformed everywhere, like pleasure and so on?
If they transform as a part, there would be the fault that in one real thing there are qualities and there are no qualities, there is blue and there is no blue, and so on.
If you say it pervades, then form and other qualities should also be called great, because they are the same as the real substance, just like earth and so on.
The real substance is in space, and the qualities reside on the real substance. The basis is different for each. How can they be the same in substance?

My intention is not to say they depend on the same substance, but only that the substance and qualities are mutually pervasive in nature. Because they are the same in size as space, I say they are the same in substance.
If qualities are called great, there should be qualities again.
However, because qualities have no qualities, they are not called great.
The opponent is not the other. One should state one's own thesis. In debate with the opponent, one describes one's own uselessness.

Or, in this case, although the difficulty with qualities is the same as the real substance being called great, the difficulty with the real substance is that it is the same as the qualities having no form, because they are the same in substance, just like form and so on.
Our school holds that earth and so on all have form and substance. How can they be the same as the qualities in having no form and obstruction?
The opponent is not the other. One should state one's own thesis. In debate with the opponent, one describes one's own uselessness.
Or else, form and so on arise in combination with real entities that are their fruits, relying on real entities that are their causes.

In the real entities that are causes, the substance of the fruit is all-pervasive, because there is no difference in location. The qualities should be like real entities and also be called great. Real entities should be like qualities and not be called great.
If it is said that our school's real entities are great but not qualities, and so they cannot be compared, that reasoning is not correct.
The opponent is not the other. One should state one's own doctrine. In debate with the opponent, one's own account is useless.

Or else, in their school, the quantity of atoms is small. When many atoms combine to produce a gross fruit, because the gross fruit and the cause have no difference in location, the atoms should become as gross as the form. The form and the gross fruit should become atoms.
If it is said that our school's cause is small but the fruit is great, and form has no shape or quantity, the reasoning is also not correct.
The opponent is not the other. One should state one's own doctrine. In debate with the opponent, one's own account is useless.

Thus, it has been explained that the existence of counted forms, etc. is devoid of real substance, and there are many fallacies. The common and uncommon natures should be refuted as they exist. The common qualities are like the counted ones. The uncommon qualities and the distinctions of actions are like the refutation of forms, etc., because they occur separately in the realities.
The VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas assert that there are only so many, which serve as the causes for the mind and speech to manifest the existence of phenomena.
Reasoning investigates and finds that none of them can be established, therefore one should not cling to them.
Moreover, a verse says:
The common and uncommon characteristics cannot manifest the characterized as nonexistent;
Apart from this, there are no other definitive causes, therefore phenomena do not exist.
The treatise states:

It has been discerned that existence, number, form, etc. cannot manifest the characterized, which is their own basis. Apart from this, there are no other definitive causes that can prove that the substance of phenomena truly exists.
It is not possible to establish the existence of phenomena without a cause, lest everything that is established be accomplished. Therefore, one cannot say that phenomena truly exist.
One should follow worldly convention and provisionally speak of it, as this is without fault and can withstand investigation. Deviating from this contradicts worldly convention and one's own tenets.
The substance, etc. upheld by the owl are non-existent, because they do not have the nature of existence, just like space flowers.
The nature of existence is also non-existent, because they are not substance, etc., just like the horns of a rabbit. Therefore, they are all false.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya says:
All dharmas do not depend on the nature of existence, etc. to be cognized, therefore the previous faults do not apply to me.
In order to refute this statement, he again speaks a verse:
Apart from the specific characteristics, there is no pot, therefore the substance of the pot is not one;
Because each individual is not a pot, therefore the substance of the pot is also not many.
The treatise says:

The substances of color, smell, taste, etc. have different specific characteristics, and are the objects of the individual sense faculties, not the objects of other sense faculties. Apart from those dharmas, there is no separate pot. Therefore, like color, etc., the substance of the pot is not one.
Since it is not admitted that there is one, the substance of the pot should be many. How can many substances be formed when each is not a pot?
The characteristics of form and so on are mutually different. How can they each form a single class of pot substance?
If the substance of each dharma were a pot, it could be called many substances when combined.
Since this is not the case, the substance of the pot is not many.
It should also not be said that the substance of the pot really exists, but it cannot be said to be one or many, because rabbit horns and turtle hair do not really exist.
Aren't form and so on combined to form an army or forest, and called one or many? Pots should also be like this.
This is only a conventional false designation of an army or forest. There is absolutely no real substance of an army or forest.
If you insist on real existence, it should be refuted like a pot. You also do not say that there is a separate army or forest.
Moreover, form, smell, and so on have no meaning of combining together, so it cannot be said that the combination is a pot.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
It is not that there is no substance of contact that combines with the substance of contact;
Therefore, dharmas such as form cannot be combined to form a pot.
The treatise says:
Combining means that their substances mutually touch each other.
This only exists in contact, referring to form, sound, smell, and taste that are not included in contact. How can they touch each other or be touched?
Since there is no contact, the meaning of combining is not established, just as without thought there is ultimately no meaning of combining.
If it is said that form, etc. have the meaning of mutual contact, they should be included in contact, just like earth, etc.

Then only the substance of contact combines with its own kind. Form and other sense objects definitely have no reasonable combination, because if they combine, they would lose the nature of form, etc.
Even if it is allowed that the aggregation of form, etc. is called combination, the nature of form, etc. is still not a real pot.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
Form is one part of the pot, therefore the substance of form is not the pot;
If the whole does not exist, how can a part exist?
The treatise says:
Color and so forth are collectively called a vase. Color is only one part, and it is not reasonable for it to be the substance of the vase.
One cannot take the vase to be a part of the vase. Sound and so forth are also to be treated in the same way.
Each one is not a vase, because they are all parts of the vase.
In this way, the parts of the vase are also unreasonable.
If the whole does not exist, what is the part of?
Each individual thing such as color does not have the substance of a vase. Apart from this, there is no real substance of a vase.
Because the substance of the vase does not exist, the parts of the vase also do not exist. How can the sense objects such as color really be the parts of a vase?

Things such as an army, a forest, and so forth are provisionally said to exist. The parts and the whole are difficult to think about in terms of identity or difference. One should speak in accordance with what is seen in the world, and one should not carefully investigate its truth.
Moreover, if the substance of color and so forth is really a vase, then everything should be a vase.
Therefore, the next verse says:
The nature of all forms and so forth, the characteristics of forms and so forth are undifferentiated;
Only one kind is a pot, the others are not - what principle is there in this?
The treatise says:
Within the basis of dependence, such as pots, clothes, and carts, the nature of the dependent, such as form and so forth, is not different in characteristics.

If the substance of form and so forth is all truly a pot, then clothes and so forth should also all be the substance of a pot, because they are the same as form and so forth, just like a commonly accepted pot.
Or the grasped pot should not be the substance of a pot, because it is the same as form and so forth, just like clothes, carts and so forth.
Form and so forth should not be the same yet different, based on which the distinctions of pots and so forth are established.

Because your school does not have any other nature of sameness or difference, and because of the distinctions of fine parts and arrangement, it does not cause the characteristics of pots and so forth to be different.

Because they are the same in taking form and so forth as their intrinsic nature, pots and so forth should not be different from form and so forth, contradicting your own accepted identity of cause and effect.
Just as there is no fault of non-difference in pots, clothes and so forth, so it is with form and so forth, because they are the same as a single pot.
It should not be said that form is different from taste, etc., but not different from the pot, etc. Therefore, the next verse says:
If form is different from taste, etc., but not different from the pot, etc.,
Then the pot, etc. are just taste, etc., how can form be the same as the pot, etc.?
The treatise says:

The pot, etc. just use taste, etc. as their substance. They should be different from form, just like taste, etc. Therefore, it cannot be said that form is different from taste, etc., but not different from the pot, etc. This is because the principle contradicts itself.

It should also not be said that each of taste, etc. is different from form, etc., but not different from the pot, etc. This is because the pot, etc. just use form, etc. as their own substance, and have no separate nature.
Thus, it has already been explained that the principle of form, etc. being the same as the pot, etc. is not established.
Now, it will be clearly shown that the principle of them being different from the pot, etc. is also not established.
Therefore, the next verse says:
Since the pot, etc. have no cause, their substance should not result.
Therefore, if they are different from form, etc., the pot, etc. would definitely be nonexistent.
The treatise says:

The substance of the great elements such as earth is formed by grasping form and so forth. Therefore, the causes of the five great elements are the five subtle elements. That is to say, by grasping the subtle element of sound, one forms the great element of space. By adding the subtle element of touch, one forms the great element of wind. By further adding the subtle element of form, one forms the great element of fire. By adding the subtle element of taste, one forms the great element of water. By comprehensively grasping the five subtle elements, one forms the great element of earth.
The great elements and the pot and so forth have the same substance and mutually form each other, because the measure of the cause is the same as the measure of the effect.
If they were different from form and so forth, the pot and so forth would have no cause.
Since they would have no cause, their substance should not be an effect, because all effects are formed in dependence on causes.

Therefore, if it is said that the pot and so forth are different from form, then the pot and so forth should not be effects or causes, because they are not form and so forth, like the hair of a turtle and so forth.
Moreover, they would not be objects of the sense faculties, because they are not causes and effects.
What is perceived by the sense faculties of form and so forth is all causes and effects. This [which is not form and so forth] is not a cause and effect, and is not perceived by the sense faculties.
Or, moreover, there should be no dharmas such as pots, because they are not causes and effects, like the son of a barren woman.
We allow that the intrinsic nature is the cause and the self is the effect, because it is manifested by the sense organs, so there is no fault of indeterminacy.
In this way, the pot and so forth established by SÄá¹ƒkhya, whether one or different, are both not established.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:
Because the fine parts such as clay give rise to the pot and so forth, the pot and so forth have a cause.
Since there is a cause, its substance is the effect.
Having a cause and being an effect, its substance is not nonexistent.
This is also not so. Therefore the next verse says:
If the cause of the pot and so forth exists, it can be the cause of the pot and so forth;
Since the cause of the pot and so forth does not exist, how can it give rise to the pot and so forth?
The treatise says:
The fine parts such as clay are established based on other dharmas. How can they be the cause to give rise to the pot and so forth?

We do not see in the world that what is established based on others, and is not self-existent, can be the cause of others. Aren't seeds and so forth able to be the cause to give rise to sprouts and so forth, even though they are established based on others?
This is the same as the difficulty, and does not save the previous fault.
The world universally knows this, so how can you raise objections?
What you hold is different from what the world knows, so in this case you are the same as those who raise objections.
The dharmas known in the world, having arisen in dependence on others, do not arise again.
They are not established independently, because they have the power to act as causes for others.
Your position is not so: dharmas that are established in dependence on others always abide in dependence on others until they cease. If the cause ceases, the effect immediately ceases.
Therefore what you hold is different from what the world knows. Without substance and without power, how can it give rise to other effects?
Or there may be a causal dharma with substance and power that can give rise to other causal dharmas.
What you hold, that particles of clay and so on are causes or that something else is a cause, is all non-existent.
Because there is no cause, the substance of clay and so on does not exist.
Without substance and without power, how can it give rise to effects?
In their doctrinal system, there are two kinds of causes, both of which can give rise to effects, namely the permanent and the impermanent.
All impermanent causes must be established in dependence on the permanent;
Because the permanent does not exist, the impermanent also does not exist.
Without a cause of the impermanent, how can the effect exist?
Therefore their cause and effect are all not established.
Furthermore, there are those who say:

The various composite substances such as pots and tiles, from the beginning, are the same kind of cause and effect, continuing in succession, following the different kinds, their substance is real and can be seen.

This is also not so. The various composite substances are gradually analyzed and return to form and so forth. Form and so forth, as previously explained, do not exist. How can there be composite substances based on them?
This composite substance, one and visible, are all as previously refuted. It should not be grasped again.
Moreover, when form and other dharmas are combined, there is no single substance. Therefore the next verse says:
When form and so forth are combined, they never become smell and so forth;
Therefore the combined single substance should be like pots and so forth, which do not exist.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

When form, etc., come together, they never transform into smell, etc. Therefore, although they combine, they do not become one substance. Do not abandon their specific characteristics and lose the names of form, etc.
For this reason, the combined one substance should be like a pot, etc. Its substance is really non-existent. This is because, like a pot, etc., apart from form, etc., there is no separate substance.
One substance is not established. The combination is also thus. This is because apart from form, etc., there is no separate substance. The substance is not established as one.
Moreover, when combining, each subtle part is not a combination. Therefore, it should be like before combining, not combining to form one subtle part, and should not be called a combination each.
Do not allow there to be many combined substances within one combination. Therefore, the combined substance does not really exist.
Moreover, the combined substance must rely on form to be established. The substance of form is still non-existent, so how can there be a combination?
As for the non-existence of the substance of form, the following verse says:
Just as apart from form, etc., the substance of a pot is really non-existent;
The substance of form should also be like this, not existing apart from wind, etc.
The treatise says:
It should be known that in this context, the four great elements and derivative form are both called form because they have the characteristic of being subject to change and destruction.

The characteristic of form that is subject to change and destruction is a composite of the great elements and derivatives, therefore apart from the great elements and derivatives there is no real substance.
It cannot be that only one of these is form, lest only this one be subject to change and destruction while the others are not.
Moreover, it cannot be that all are form, lest all forms be of the same substance. If the substance is different, it should lose the nature of form.

It cannot be that a single nature has many substances, lest all dharmas be of the same nature. Therefore the name form has no real substance. It is only on the basis of wind, etc. that the name form is provisionally established.

Just as the substance of form is empty, so too are feeling, etc. The real substance is not found when the characteristics of being experienced, etc. are examined. There are only worldly provisional names and characteristics.
If there are no great elements and derivatives, how can there be such functions as burning and cooking in the world with things like fire?
Moreover, if everything is completely nonexistent, then all the established [phenomena] should not be able to exist.

I do not say that the substance and function of all dharmas do not exist, but I say that what your treatise establishes is all nonexistent. This means that the substance of form, feeling, etc. known in the world, and the function of burning, cooking, etc., are all not nonexistent.
If the substance and function grasped by the inverted views of discrimination by foolish common people, I say they do not exist.
It is not that the noble ones see them as existent, because the grasping by false emotions is completely nonexistent.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika says:

Fire is the burner and earth is the burned. Their substance is real, and the function of burning, cooking, etc. also truly exists, because the changes in color due to cooking, etc. are presently knowable.
Now, we should question:
What is burned by fire?
Is it heat or something else?
You should carefully answer.
What is the fault of both accepting?
Both are not correct.
Why is that?
Therefore, the next verse says:
Heat is precisely the nature of fire. How can something not hot burn?
Therefore, the substance of firewood is nonexistent, apart from this fire is not existent.
The treatise says:

Heat is not what is burned, because it is the nature of fire. It contradicts the apparent fact that it has its own function. Moreover, in your school, what is burned is not heat, so you should not grasp heat as what is burned.
You should also not say that what is burned is earth, because it is not of the nature of heat, just like water and wind.
Firewood is what is burned, because what is burned does not exist, the substance of firewood does not exist.
Since the substance of firewood does not exist, what does fire depend on to be established?
Fire must depend on firewood to arise, when what is burned, firewood, is exhausted, fire is then nonexistent.
Since what burns and what is burned both do not exist, how can the color and so forth produced by cooking really exist?
Therefore, grasping that what burns, what is burned, and the function of cooking and so forth really exist is all unreasonable.

Some say that this verse not only refutes the VaiÅ›eá¹£ika non-Buddhists who say that earth is what is burned, but generally refutes the statement that dharmas such as earth, because they are not of the nature of heat, are not the substance that is heated.
This explanation is not correct.
Because it is not of the nature of heat, and since there is no similar example, the reason must be incomplete.

One cannot say that just as before it is burned, a mass of earth, etc., is not what is burned, because the nature of heat always exists in that mass, and because it is also called what is burned, since it follows the change in appearance.
The dharmas of pleasure, suffering, etc., are also called what is burned because they are called what is burned by the change in the supporting body due to fire.
The dharmas of the formless realm are also called what is burned because they are attracted by the prior stages and lower stages. Therefore the similar example cited by the reason is not correct.
Even if it were a similar example, the principle is still incorrect.
The names what is burned and what is not burned are commonly recognized by the world to exist only in tangible objects, not in other dharmas.
Although the name what is not burned is common to other dharmas, it is restricted to the same class, just like the word nonreal.
Moreover, the Hinayana does not hold that there are real dharmas such as what is burned, etc., so why bother to refute them?
If you say that you refute their conventional what is burned, then you contradict the world. How can you establish a logical argument?
Next, the non-Buddhist Nirgrantha says:

Although the ultimate atoms of earth and other fruits are not fire, they combine with fire. Because they are mixed with fire, the appearance of heat arises. However, those earth, etc. are truly not burned, because their nature is different from heat;
They are also not not burned, because they resemble the appearance of heat.
Although they cannot be said to be both, they are actually what is burned.
This is also not so. Therefore, the next verse says:
How can the rest become fire by becoming heat?
If the rest do not become heat, the principle of fire should not exist.

The treatise says:ğŸ”½If the earth and other elements truly become heat because they are mixed with fire, they should be made to become fire, because they are included in the heat touch, just like the real fire element.

If the rest do not become heat because they are mixed with fire, then the various dharmas that are born from fire as their cause and transform into the different touches should also not exist, just as fire cannot produce other heat touches.
If there is no cooked color, etc., what can be burned?
Who can be burned?
Therefore burning, etc., do not really exist.ğŸ”½Fire is not really able to burn, because it is included in the category of touch, like the earth element, etc.
Earth is not really burned, because it is included in the category of touch, like the fire element, etc.
Cooking the cooker should be refuted in the same way. Therefore their doctrine is not established.
Next, we should ask the followers of the SÄá¹ƒkhya school again:
Do the particles of fire have fuel or not?
If not, that is unreasonable.
Therefore the next verse says:
If the fire particles have no fuel, fire should exist apart from fuel.
The treatise says:
If the particles of fire exist apart from fuel, the gross fire should be the same as them and not depend on fuel.
If it does not depend on fuel, then it should have no function of burning, etc., like the particles of fire.
If so, then it should lose its nature as fire, having no function of burning, like earth, water, and wind.

We do not see such a fire in the world, without the function of burning and cooking and apart from fuel, therefore fire atoms must exist in dependence on fuel, just as we presently see fire dependent on fuel.
Or one should believe and know that atoms are not fire, because they lack the function of fire, just like the hair of a turtle.
This is also not so, therefore the next verse says:
If fire atoms have fuel, there should be no fire atoms.
The treatise says:
If fire atoms always combine with fuel, they should be called coarse fire. What is meant by atoms?
Because they always combine with fuel, they should be like coarse fire and lose their atomic nature.
Earth combining with them also does not form atoms, and the rest should also be so, because their types are the same. Then one should definitely conclude that there is not a single atom.
Just as form dharmas are like this, so are mind dharmas. Because mind and mental dharmas arise and cease together.
Moreover, the single essence of all dharmas is not established.
Why is this so?
Therefore the next verse says:
When carefully observing all phenomena, there is not a single real entity.
The treatise states:
All conditioned phenomena depend on causes and conditions to arise, accumulating and arising, accumulating and ceasing. There is not a single dharma whose substance exists independently.
Within a single substance, further gradual analysis is made, down to the most subtle, which still has many parts.
If the substance of all dharmas is not one, it should be many. This is also unreasonable.
Therefore, the next verse says:
Since a single substance does not exist, multiple substances should also be non-existent.
The treatise states:
It is necessary to first have one, and then accumulate to form many.
Since a single substance does not exist, how can multiple substances exist?
Moreover, you assert that one depends on conditions to give rise to many. Since a single substance does not exist, how can multiple substances exist?
The non-existence of a single substance has already been fully discussed. Therefore, there definitely are no truly existent multiple substances.
Although what they grasp as one self exists alone, its substance is all-encompassing and combines with many selves.
Moreover, many dharmas combined cannot constitute a single substance. Since the single cannot be established, how can the many be established?
Isn't it that emptiness, etc. are unique and without a second, and the world universally understands them to be a single substance?

What the world universally knows is provisional, not real. What you grasp as real is not known in the world. How can you know that the single substance of emptiness, etc. is only provisionally existent?
Therefore, the next verse says:
If a dharma has no other, you say it is a single substance;
Since all dharmas have the three natures, the single substance is non-existent.
The treatise says:
If it is said that dharmas have no other companions and exist alone, they are called one.

Each of the substances of emptiness, etc. has the three natures, namely existence, oneness, and substance. Existence refers to universal existence, oneness refers to the number one, and substance refers to the category of substances, which is one of the three: substance, quality, and action. Therefore, each of the dharmas such as space has the three natures.
If it were not so, then the words â€œone cognitionâ€ could not be applied to space, etc.
Since there is no single dharma that exists alone, how can it be said that there is a single substance?

If it is said that the word â€œoneâ€ refers to real entities, etc., and therefore only real entities, etc. are called â€œone thing,â€ then because there is one but there is no one, the words â€œone cognitionâ€ should not be able to arise.
If it is said that there is no error in the hypothetical case, this is also not so, because it has already been refuted previously.
That is, who is real and who is hypothetical among the cognition, words, etc.?
They should all be real or both be hypothetical.
Moreover, although the characteristics of all dharmas are different, they should be able to be called real, with qualities or functions. Therefore, they are hypothetically said to be so.
The error is even deeper and cannot be removed in the end.

One becomes three errors: first, the identity of the three natures is not established; second, since one is not established, three also do not exist; therefore, the dharmas are neither one nor many. It is said that one and many are hypothetical, not real.

There is another interpretation that one dharma is established as three natures. The words â€œone dharmaâ€ exclude that which is not one. The two kinds of extremely subtle that are not one exclude the two and the previous, thus establishing two natures. The fundamental dharma substance is the third. Therefore all dharmas have three natures.
Now we should ask:
The exclusion of the two and the taking of the one is the discrimination of the mind itself having differences. How can it cause the dharmas to become the three natures?

Moreover, the exclusion of the previous two establishes the one. That which is neither two nor many is called one. Therefore, the establishment of the one reverses the three. How can it be said that the three refute the one?

There is another interpretation that one dharma is established as three natures. The exclusion of the three non-existents of past, present, and future establishes the three natures. For example, the exclusion of the non-king and so forth establishes the name. This exclusion of the three non-existents establishes the three natures.
This interpretation is unreasonable.
Why is it so?
The different kinds are boundless. How can they only be three kinds? The exclusion of the non-existent and the establishment of the existent, the non-existence is not only three;
The names established are over a thousand in number.
How can you say that only one dharma is established as three?
Moreover, distinguishing characteristics are only in one's own mind or in names and expressions. What does this have to do with the essence of dharmas?
Therefore, this explanation is powerless to refute [the opponent's position].
There is another explanation:
Permanence has already been refuted earlier. Now this only refutes the attachment to impermanence.
The impermanence that is grasped all has three natures, namely arising, abiding, and ceasing, as shown in various sÅ«tras.
This is also incorrect. The characteristics of arising, abiding, and ceasing are different in time, just as suffering, joy, and indifference must not occur at the same time.
Since the times are not the same, the essential characteristics are also different. How can it be called one dharma with three natures?
Moreover, if it is said that arising is immediately followed by ceasing, it should be said to have two natures. How can it be discussed as three?
Moreover, arising and ceasing occur at different times, just like the past and future worlds. They cannot be called one dharma. How can it be argued that one dharma has two natures?
Therefore, this explanation is also logically untenable.
There is another interpretation:
All conditioned dharmas are momentary. In a single moment there are many moments of time, just as there are ká¹£aá¹‡as, etc.
The term three natures shows that the natures are not unitary, and that there are not only three.
This is not so, because the temporal distinctions of past, future, and present are not one dharma. How can it be said that one dharma has three natures?
Therefore the former interpretation is the best.

Each dharma is neither one nor many. In accordance with conventional expressions, it is said that there is multiplicity and unity. Conventional dharmas are provisionally established as existent in accordance with conventional feelings and ideas, and cannot be investigated further.
All wise people should follow conventional expressions and say that dharmas exist, and should not insist on seeking them.

If one seeks the nature and characteristics of conventional dharmas by seeking, it is no different from a person holding a lamp and entering a dark room to seek the nature and characteristics of darkness.
Why is this?

The various conventional dharmas are like illusions and darkness, formed by the aggregation of conditions, and cannot withstand investigation and inquiry. If investigated, they immediately disintegrate.
Next, in order to show that all dharmas grasped by the world are not real, and to show that the graspings of the non-Buddhists are not the same, the following verse is spoken:
Existence, non-existence, both existence and non-existence, one, not one, and both affirmation and negation;
They should be matched in order, and the wise should understand that they are not real.
The treatise states:

All worldly meanings of form and so forth, expressed by names and phrases, known by the mind and wisdom, have different emotional graspings, which can be summarized into four types: existence, non-existence, both affirmation and negation, and neither affirmation nor negation.
They should be matched in order with the four mistaken graspings, namely one, not one, both affirmation and negation, and neither affirmation nor negation.
The SÄá¹ƒkhya non-Buddhist path grasps the nature of existence and so forth as being the same as the various dharmas, which corresponds to the phrase existence.
This grasping is not real.
Why is it so?
If blue and so forth are the same as the nature of form, they should be the same as the nature of form in substance.
If the five sounds such as pleasure are the same as the nature of sound, they should be the same as the nature of sound in substance. Smell, taste, and touch should be the same.

If the different characteristics of sameness and difference are said to be the same in substance, then all dharmas should be without difference.
Since different characteristics do not exist, how can the characteristic of sameness exist?
Because the two characteristics of sameness and difference are established in mutual dependence.

If they are only a negation, there should be nothing to be grasped.
Negation and affirmation are logically mutually contradictory;

You grasp that the nature and characteristics of all dharmas are not empty, and speak of the double negation, only to avoid faults. This double negation statement should also not be discussed, because it contradicts the nature and characteristics of dharmas as you hold them.

Thus, the four kinds of non-Buddhist doctrines in the world, with their evil views that disturb and destroy the mind, falsely speculate on the natures and characteristics of dharmas, all of which are not in accord with reason.

In order to reveal this meaning, another verse is spoken:
In the provisional dharma of continuity, evil views think it is truly permanent;
In the provisional dharma of accumulation, wrong attachments say it is truly existent.
The treatise says:

The arising and ceasing of conditioned dharmas, from the past to the future, have been continuously passing on since beginningless time. The subtle changes in arising and ceasing are difficult to know, and the continuity of cause and effect seems like one thing.
Foolish people, with their evil views, think it is truly permanent. Wrong attachments are entangled and they slander each other.

Dharmas such as form rely on causes and conditions, and are provisionally accumulated without any real substance. The subtle accumulation is closely connected and difficult to distinguish, and the many parts are indistinctly similar to one.
Fools are biased and attached, saying that there are real entities, each holding to one path and engaging in disputes with each other.

Moreover, within the continuity and accumulation of the provisional, not understanding that the various gates and states are provisionally existent, they falsely imagine various meanings to be different, grasping that within one dharma there are many real natures.

In this way, the confusion regarding self-nature and distinctions all arises from evil views and wrong attachments. Relying on this, one cycles through the destinies and existences, experiencing various sufferings without any hope of escape.

Therefore, one should eliminate evil views and wrong attachments, and believe and understand that all dharmas are assembled through causes and conditions, being provisional and not real, without inverted principles.

Furthermore, in order to show that all dharmas are formed through the convergence of many conditions, being neither singular nor permanent, without self or dharmas, like magical illusions, existing in sentiment but not in principle, being conventional and not true,
another verse is spoken:
All dharmas are formed through the convergence of many conditions, their nature weak and without independence;
The dependent is established as empty, therefore neither self nor dharmas exist.

All dharmas are false and deceptive, formed from the convergence of many conditions. They arise and abide dependent on others, with no independent essence. Moment by moment, they are born and perish, composed of many parts. They are neither unitary nor permanent, like illusions and transformations.
Fools grasp at their existence, while the wise understand their non-existence. Therefore, within them there is no self and no dharmas.
All non-Buddhists and other vehicles consider oneness and permanence to be the self and dharmas.
One and permanent do not exist, and self and dharmas are definitely non-existent. Therefore, explaining dependent origination reveals the two kinds of no-self.
Furthermore, there are those who say:

Words, phrases, and sentences combine to express one's own mind and the meaning one wishes to speak. Each is distinct and, although unable to express [the meaning], when combined they can convey [the meaning].
If the meaning does not exist, the expression should also be non-existent;
since there is that which can express, there must definitely be a meaning.
In order to refute this view, the next verse is spoken:
The effect is formed by the convergence of many conditions. Apart from the conditions, there is no separate effect.
In this way, the convergence and the effect, the sages understand all to be non-existent.
The treatise states:
The meaning of this verse is as follows: Unconditioned dharmas are not produced from conditions, like a flower in the sky, with no essence or function at all, as extensively explained above.

Conditioned dharmas are produced from the convergence of many conditions, like an illusion, with no real essence or function. When conditions come together, results are produced, and the results are not separate from the conditions, like a tree forming a forest, and the forest not being different from the trees.
Condensing conditions to form results accords with conventional expressions, but in the principle of ultimate truth, there is no such thing, so the sages understand that they are all non-existent.
Why is this so?

Names and phrases are both composed of letters, and letters also take many parts as their essence. Each letter is composed of many moments, with no meaning of combination between the preceding and subsequent moments. The preceding moment must cease before the subsequent moment arises.
When arising, there is ceasing; this principle is certain. The non-existent and the existent cannot form a combined meaning.
The two times, preceding and subsequent, also do not combine, because the time periods are different, just like the past and future.
Since the combined meaning does not exist, how can the individual letters exist?
Since there are no individual letters, how can the letter forms be established?
Since the letter forms do not exist, names and phrases do not exist.
Without letters, names, and phrases, the combination of meanings cannot be formed. How can it be said that the combination of letters, names, and phrases can express meaning?

However, in the world, according to one's own mental transformations, it is said that many letters combine to form names, and many names combine to form phrases. It is said that these names and phrases can express meaning.
The expounder and the expressed are all transformations of one's own mind. In the transformations of the mind, there is emotion but no principle. The sages truly know and see this.
How do they know and see?
It is said that they see those dharmas as all being created by the deluded discriminating mind of foolish people, as provisional and not real, as existing conventionally but not truly existing.

In accordance with the world, it is said that they exist provisionally. Therefore, all that can be expressed and that which is expressed exist conventionally but not truly. One should not insist on them.
Furthermore, regarding all objects, the view of emptiness and non-self can quickly accomplish one's own benefit and the benefit of others.
Why is this so?
Foolish people grasp at self and mine regarding objects, and revolve in the cycle of birth and death.
The sages penetrate emptiness and non-self in this regard, quickly realize permanence and bliss, and are able to skillfully benefit others.
Therefore, one should cultivate the view of emptiness and non-self, causing one's own benefit to be fulfilled and wondrous function to be inexhaustible.
In order to show that this view is the true and essential path for benefiting oneself and others, a verse is spoken:
Consciousness is the seed of all existences; objects are what consciousness cognizes.
When one sees objects as devoid of self, the seeds of all existences are extinguished.
The treatise says:

Consciousness is able to give rise to afflictions and karma, and through this, the three existences and the cycle of birth and death revolve. Therefore, it is said that the conscious mind is the seed of all existences, and is able to attract future existences, obtaining the name of consciousness-food.
In this way, the conscious mind arises in dependence on form and other [objects], and if there are no objects to be cognized, consciousness will definitely not arise.
If one is able to contemplate the object as being without self, then since the object of perception does not exist, the perceiving subject also does not exist.

When the object and subject are both gone, then all suffering is extinguished. One realizes the tranquil, shadowless, cool and refreshing nirvana. When one reaches this stage, it is called the fulfillment of one's own benefit.
One's original vows are for the benefit of others. Abiding in this stage, one's transformative activity is inexhaustible, and one also causes sentient beings to realize this nirvana.
Therefore, those who wish to seek the true skillful means for the benefit of self and others should diligently cultivate the view of emptiness and no-self.

There is another explanation:ğŸ”½As for consciousness being the seed of all existence, it means that various habitual tendencies are perfumed and formed in the store consciousness. Due to the increase of ignorance, existence, and craving, one is able to experience the three kinds of existence and the cycle of birth and death. Consciousness serves as the basis, and therefore it is called consciousness.

As for the object being what is traversed by consciousness, the habitual tendencies in consciousness are perfumed and formed by grasping form and other objects. The bound object is called what is traversed because it serves as the basis.

When one sees that objects have no self means that when one contemplates all objects and their characteristics as empty through the view of no-self, all seeds are extinguished means that through the view of no-self, one permanently severs the two latent tendencies of ignorance and craving for existence.
This is because these two are the causes that give rise to karma and also moisten karma, causing it to produce results.

When these two are severed, karmic results do not arise. At that time, all seeds of conceptualized phenomena and afflictive phenomena are severed together, and thus it is said that all are extinguished. It does not mean that all kinds of consciousness and so forth are completely nonexistent.
Why is this?
When the noble path arises, it only extinguishes all habitual tendencies of false conceptualization and discourse, causing defiled dharmas to never arise again.
For one type of sentient being, all undefiled dharmas are also completely severed because they have no basis.

One class of sentient beings, by the power of their original vows, continuously maintain their uncontaminated consciousnesses without interruption, and are able to serve as the basis for boundless virtues such as unsurpassed, vast, profound, unobstructed eloquence, and so forth.
Moreover, by the power of consciousness and so forth, they perfect and ultimately realize spiritual powers and functions, continuing on into the future without effort.

All of this is due to the power of their original vows and practices, which give rise to inexhaustible virtues for their own benefit and the benefit of others, enabling sentient beings to mature and attain liberation, with marvelous functions continuing on into the distant future.
Therefore, one should cultivate the view of emptiness and no-self, and abandon all extreme attachments.
